success.

2374.41.text: So what do our teams do?

2375.97.text: Our teams are scouring you know, the world

2379.60.text:
for great products, and great stories, and
great brands.

2384.09.text: We also have ideas, and we create them.

2386.23.text:
You know, what we're doing with Disney for
example, at the end of this month.

2389.49.text: We saw Oz the Great and Powerful.

2391.71.text:
So we're Disney partner for Maleficent,
which is launching going

2396.36.text:
into theaters at the end of March with
Angelina Jolie.

2399.88.text:
So we went out to 50 different brands from
small to big

2403.59.text:
and we had people create products inspired
by the inspiration of the story.

2409.30.text: And we're creating a 24-hour event on air.

2412.25.text:
So, you have a little entrepreneurial
brand next to, you know, a big brand.

2417.51.text:
But what they're all doing is just
creating inspiring stories.

2421.71.text:
And that's what's exciting for us, is to
be able to do

2431.74.text:
>> Hi, my name is Gillian [INAUDIBLE] I'm
an MBA too.

2433.71.text:
My question is around how your see you're
role and you're objective as a

2437.59.text: CEO today, and I'm wondering how that's

2439.87.text:
changed since you took the role on
initially?

2444.51.text:
>> So, you know, I look at the, the CEO
role as on multiple levels right?

2450.78.text:
I am responsible for making sure I'm
creating sustainable

2455.95.text:
value for my company, which is going to
ultimately then

2460.80.text:
create value for all the constituencies we
have, whether

2465.86.text:
it's our customers, our employees or our
shareholders.

2472.95.text:
But I'm also responsible for being the
shepherd of my brands and for my company.

2479.92.text: And I'm also responsible for creating

2482.66.text:
sustainable opportunities and success for
people.

2488.25.text:
And I take all of that very, very
seriously.

2492.58.text: And I say all of that because sometimes,

2494.74.text:
to your earlier point, they can be
conflicting priorities.

2497.75.text: There are times where, you know, I have to

2501.41.text:
make a decision, and I've not made the
decision to

2505.77.text:
make money in that quarter, because I'm
not gonna make

2510.55.text:
the wrong decision for the long term of
the business.

2516.03.text:
But I'm very clear about why I decided to
do something, and my share holders

2521.07.text:
understand because I've been consistent
with our strategy and our story.

2526.13.text: For six years I've never deviated, so they

2529.01.text:
trust the decisions that I'm making, even
though

2532.35.text: it might have a short term disruption, are

2535.15.text:
right for the long term value of the
business.

2538.19.text: Which is why I think we have long term

2540.43.text:
shareholders and great institutions
because that really is my job.

2544.85.text:
Is to understand the choices and to make
the right

2548.44.text:
and educated choices for the long term
success of the company.

2553.10.text:
The second thing, is my job as a CEO to
really lead and be a role model

2559.63.text:
for what I do and what I say, both
internally and externally.

2566.79.text: And it's to set the, an example.

2569.73.text:
And I take that really seriously, because
the worst thing that I

2572.87.text:
could do, is sit up here and say, we do
all of this.

2576.01.text:
And then all of a sudden, I act
differently.

2580.87.text: It's not real and it's not authentic.

2584.31.text:
So I have to kind of live, and walk the
walk.

2587.67.text:
And whether it be about, you know, why we
launched Davidson Cares?

2592.12.text: Or what we have to invest in, or if I

2594.22.text:
do have to, you know, consolidate a
business, and maybe I

2597.85.text:
do have to layoff some people, because, if
I don't,

2601.18.text:
I can't deploy the resources that will
take the company forward.

2605.68.text:
But anyone that knows me, knows that if I
do that, I'm gonna do it respectfully.

2610.91.text:
And people are gonna understand the
reasons why.

2614.14.text:
So I look at that role in very broad
terms.

2619.40.text:
>> Mindy, most of us here today are
thinking

2621.83.text:
about what to do next now that school is
wrapping

2624.61.text:
up and charting career paths of our own
with some

2627.39.text:
uncertainty, and this is a quote that you
said last

2630.38.text:
year at in New York, and this is something
that

2633.37.text:
I know you tell your daughter, I'm
wondering if you

2636.43.text:
could expand on it in closing for us as
MBAs

2638.86.text:
and how you might encourage us to leap
into it.

2641.61.text:
>> I think it's really important that
people not be afraid of risk.

2649.77.text:
Now, there is a big difference between
risk and suicide, okay.

2653.65.text: I just want to be clear.

2654.57.text:
And what I mean by that is, don't only
look at what's in front of you today.

2661.11.text: Don't only look at what's out there today.

2664.09.text:
Find, take the insights of everything that
you've learned.

2668.17.text:
Take the insights and intellectual
curiosity

2670.82.text: you have to look what's out there.

2672.83.text: And say what do I want to be part of?

2676.25.text:
What do I want, you know, what do I want
to get that experience, right?

2681.83.text: What do I see as growing?

2684.37.text:
What do I see as, you know, that, that
next thing?

2688.42.text:
It's kind of like we're looking at a lot
of acquisitions right now and

2691.08.text: I'm looking for those things that are

2692.52.text:
going to have the big growth
opportunities, right?

2696.57.text: And you have to decide what level of risk

2698.56.text:
you're gonna take at any given point in
your career.

2701.96.text: But the time when you can really do it

2703.89.text:
and have the different experiences is, is
early, right?

2707.57.text:
I, I had a, I had a number of friends who
I said to them, you are miserable, right?

2713.49.text: Why are you still doing this?

2716.16.text: Never be in a position to feel trapped.

2719.60.text:
Believe in yourself enough that you need
to find those things that are.

2722.96.text:
Cuz if you are inspired, and you are
excited, and you are apart

2726.36.text: of something, you are probably gonna be

2728.54.text:
successful because you're doing what you
love.

2731.58.text:
And you know, it's interesting, my husband
went to school, got his

2735.87.text: undergraduate, his maters and his post

2738.34.text:
graduate in applied mathematics and
physics.

2741.26.text:
He's like a real geek, he said he was
Steven Hawkins, right.

2744.07.text:
And he goes I don't think I wanna do it,
then he went to law school,

2747.03.text: you know, and then he went, and he

2748.35.text:
practiced law for five years, and he was
miserable.

2751.33.text:
And, this kinda went, I, I met him, and he
said you know what, I, I can't do this.

2755.99.text:
And he just decided to give up law and
made a segue

2759.16.text:
and said, I wanna figure out maybe how to
go into banking

2762.55.text:
which he did, and he went and he said I'm
gonna make

2765.66.text:
my segue from, into derivatives and swap
documentation and went into finance.

2772.18.text:
>> but, but you know, he's always been one
of those people

2775.35.text:
that, you know, at his true heart and soul
I think he's

2778.45.text:
an academic, but he's got this incredible
intellectual curiosity and the most

2782.94.text:
important thing for him is, I need to fill
my intellectual curiosity.

2786.92.text: So that was always his guiding post.

2789.74.text:
You know, mine was I gotta be inspired and
I have to

2792.78.text:
be creative, and I have to have an outlet
for my creativity.

2796.35.text:
The most important thing you can do, and
the most empowering

2800.06.text:
thing you will ever do throughout your
entire life, is know yourself.

2806.89.text:
I think self-awareness is the key to
everything.

2810.60.text:
>> We spend a lot of time on that [LAUGH]
here at Stanford Business School.

2814.20.text:
Know, know the good, the bad, and the
ugly.

2817.98.text:
>> Trust me, you know, I know what my
derailers are, right?

2822.77.text:
But, it's empowering if you know what
you're made of, because then you

2826.16.text:
can put those things through the filter of
what's real and what's important.

2830.61.text:
And, when people work for you, if you're
really honest,

2833.74.text:
and you're willing to tell people what
your strengths are, and

2837.13.text:
your willing to tell them what your
weaknesses are, there gonna

2840.51.text:
trust you a lot more, because your willing
to share that.

2844.54.text:
And we have a joke, we all know what our
derailers are.

2846.94.text: Mine, I'm not very patient sometimes.

2850.65.text:
One of the other guys is mischievous, so
he'll try and you know?

2854.27.text:
When, when you're under stress, you have
to know what it is.

2856.50.text:
So we can be in a meeting, and we'll be
able to call each other out.

2862.78.text:
And I, I just think it's, you know,
self-awareness is empowering.

2867.67.text:
So know everything you can about yourself,
know

2870.35.text:
what gets you excited, and then find that
path.

2873.04.text:
>> Mindy thank you so much for being here
with me.
